item.title: Lecture 01 â€” What Is AI, Really?
item.description:
~2 hours (foundational lecture)

ğŸ§  The Big Question

What does it mean for a machine to be intelligent?

Before tools, before code, before models â€”
we must understand what intelligence actually is.

Is intelligence:

  • memorizing facts?
  • following rules?
  • learning from experience?
  • reasoning?
  • creating new ideas?

AI forces us to rethink what it means to think.

ğŸ§© A Short History of AI (Very Important)

1ï¸âƒ£ Rule-Based Systems (Old AI)

Early AI worked like this:

IF email contains "free money"
THEN mark as spam

âœ… Works for simple cases âŒ Breaks when rules explode

If intelligence = rules, then more rules = smarter machine?

No.

2ï¸âƒ£ Learning-Based Systems (Modern AI)

Instead of rules, we show examples:

  • spam email âŒ
  • normal email âœ…

The machine learns patterns.

This shift is called Machine Learning.

ğŸŒ± AI for Kids (and Adults)

Imagine teaching a robot:

ğŸ¶ What is a dog? ğŸ± What is a cat?

Two ways:

âŒ Rule Way

  • Dogs have 4 legs
  • Dogs bark
  • Dogs have fur

What about:

  • toy dogs?
  • robots?
  • pictures?

Rules break.

âœ… Learning Way

Show many examples.

The robot learns patterns.

ğŸ‘‰ This is Machine Learning.

ğŸ§  What Is Machine Learning?

Machine Learning = Learning patterns from data to make predictions or decisions

Instead of:

  • writing rules

We:

  • collect data
  • define objectives
  • let the model learn

ğŸ¤– What Is AI (Simple Definition)

Artificial Intelligence is a system that perceives, learns, reasons, and acts to achieve goals.

Key words:

  • Perceive (see, hear, read)
  • Learn (from data)
  • Reason (make decisions)
  • Act (produce output)

ğŸ§  Narrow AI vs Human Intelligence

Human AI
General intelligence Narrow intelligence
Learns few examples Needs lots of data
Understands meaning Learns patterns
Has values Needs alignment

AI today is powerful but narrow.

ğŸ§  From ML to Deep Learning

ğŸ”¹ Machine Learning

  • Uses features
  • Human-designed representations

ğŸ”¹ Deep Learning

  • Learns features automatically
  • Uses neural networks

Deep Learning made AI work at scale.

ğŸ§  What Is a Neural Network?

Inspired by the brain (loosely).

Basic idea:

Input â†’ Layers â†’ Output

It learns:

  • weights
  • connections
  • representations

Neural networks power:

  • vision
  • speech
  • language
  • games

ğŸ—£ï¸ What Is NLP?

NLP = Natural Language Processing

Goal:

Teach machines to understand human language.

Examples:

  • translation
  • chatbots
  • summarization
  • search

ğŸ“š What Is an LLM?

LLM = Large Language Model

Examples:

  • GPT
  • Gemini
  • Claude

LLMs are trained on:

  • books
  • code
  • websites
  • conversations

Key idea:

LLMs predict the next word â€” very well.

Butâ€¦

  • prediction â‰  understanding
  • fluency â‰  truth

ğŸ’¬ How ChatGPT Really Works (Simple)

ChatGPT:

  1. Reads your input
  2. Converts words â†’ numbers
  3. Uses a Transformer model
  4. Predicts the next token
  5. Repeats

It feels intelligent because:

  • patterns of language encode reasoning

But it does not think like humans.

ğŸ¨ What Is Generative AI?

Generative AI creates new content

Types:

  • Text âœï¸
  • Images ğŸ–¼ï¸
  • Audio ğŸ§
  • Video ğŸ¥
  • Code ğŸ’»

It does not copy. It samples from learned distributions.

ğŸ–¼ï¸ Diffusion Models (Image AI)

Used in:

  • Stable Diffusion
  • DALLÂ·E

Idea:

  1. Add noise to images
  2. Learn how to remove noise
  3. Generate new images from noise

Creation = reversing chaos.

ğŸ­ What Is GAN?

GAN = Generative Adversarial Network

Two models:

  • Generator ğŸ¨ (creates fake)
  • Discriminator ğŸ•µï¸ (detects fake)

They compete.

Result:

  • very realistic images
  • unstable training

GANs taught us:

Creativity can emerge from competition.

ğŸ¤– What Is an AI Agent?

An AI agent is a system that can observe, decide, and act autonomously.

Agent = LLM + tools + memory + goals

Examples:

  • AutoGPT
  • AI assistants
  • Game-playing bots

ğŸ§  What Is Agentic AI?

Agentic AI means:

  • planning
  • tool usage
  • multi-step reasoning
  • self-reflection

Not just answering â€” but doing.

This is the future direction of AI.

ğŸ§  Intelligence â‰  Consciousness

Important truth:

AI:

  • âŒ has no emotions
  • âŒ has no awareness
  • âŒ has no intent

It simulates intelligence.

Humans:

  • have values
  • have meaning
  • have responsibility

âš ï¸ Why Ethics Matters

AI learns from us.

Bias in data â†’ bias in AI Power without wisdom â†’ danger

Smart systems require wise humans.

âœ… Final Takeaways

  • AI is not magic
  • AI is math + data + optimization
  • Intelligence can be simulated
  • Understanding matters more than tools

ğŸŒ± Final Reflection

If AI becomes very intelligent, what should remain uniquely human?

Values, ethics, responsibility, wisdom.

item.title: Lecture 02 â€” Python: The Language of AI
item.description:
~2â€“3 hours (core recap lecture)

ğŸ Why Python?

Python is the language of thinking for AI and algorithms.

It is used in:

  • ğŸ¤– Artificial Intelligence
  • ğŸ“Š Data Science
  • ğŸ§  Research & prototyping
  • ğŸ§© Coding interviews (LeetCode, Google, Meta)

If you know Python well, you can think clearly.

ğŸ§  Mental Model (IMPORTANT)

Before syntax, remember this:

Python executes line by line, top to bottom.
Variables point to objects.
Everything is an object.

This mental model helps you avoid 80% of bugs.

1ï¸âƒ£ Variables & Data Types

ğŸ“¦ Variables

x = 10
name = "AI"
pi = 3.14
is_active = True

Python is dynamically typed:

x = 10
x = "now a string"

ğŸ”¢ Core Data Types

Type Example
int 10
float 3.14
str "hello"
bool True, False
None None

â“ Quiz

Is Python statically typed?

No. Python is dynamically typed.

2ï¸âƒ£ Control Flow (if / else)

x = 5

if x > 0:
    print("Positive")
elif x == 0:
    print("Zero")
else:
    print("Negative")

ğŸ§  Interview Tip

Indentation is logic in Python.

â“ Quiz

What happens if indentation is wrong?

The program raises an IndentationError or behaves incorrectly.

3ï¸âƒ£ Loops (for / while)

ğŸ” for-loop (most common)

for i in range(5):
    print(i)

ğŸ”„ while-loop

count = 0
while count < 3:
    print(count)
    count += 1

ğŸ§  Interview Tip

Use for unless you must use while.

â“ Quiz

When is while-loop dangerous?

When the stopping condition is incorrect â†’ infinite loop.

4ï¸âƒ£ Lists (Most Important for LeetCode)

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]

Common operations

nums.append(5)
nums.pop()
nums[0]
nums[-1]
len(nums)

Looping over list

for n in nums:
    print(n)

With index

for i, n in enumerate(nums):
    print(i, n)

â“ Quiz

What is the time complexity of list append?

Amortized O(1)

5ï¸âƒ£ Strings (Text = Sequence)

s = "machine"

Strings behave like lists:

s[0]        # 'm'
s[-1]       # 'e'
s[1:4]      # 'ach'

Useful methods

s.lower()
s.upper()
s.split()

â“ Quiz

Are strings mutable?

No. Strings are immutable.

6ï¸âƒ£ Dictionaries (Keyâ€“Value Thinking)

student = {
    "name": "Kao",
    "age": 25,
    "major": "AI"
}

Access

student["name"]
student.get("age")

Loop

for key, value in student.items():
    print(key, value)

ğŸ§  Interview Tip

Dictionaries give O(1) average lookup.

â“ Quiz

Why are dictionaries powerful?

Fast lookup using hashing.

7ï¸âƒ£ Sets (Uniqueness)

nums = [1, 2, 2, 3]
unique = set(nums)

Use cases

  • Remove duplicates
  • Fast membership check
if 3 in unique:
    print("Found")

â“ Quiz

Does a set preserve order?

No.

8ï¸âƒ£ Functions (Reusable Thinking)

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

Default arguments

def greet(name="AI"):
    print("Hello", name)

â“ Quiz

Why use functions?

Abstraction, reuse, clarity.

9ï¸âƒ£ Common Built-ins (LeetCode Gold)

len()
sum()
min()
max()
sorted()
range()

Example:

nums = [3, 1, 2]
sorted(nums)

ğŸ”Ÿ Time Complexity Awareness (VERY IMPORTANT)

Operation Typical Cost
List access O(1)
Dict lookup O(1)
List search O(n)
Sorting O(n log n)

Python coding interviews are algorithm interviews, not syntax tests.

ğŸ§  Python for AI Mindset

Python is:

  • ğŸ§© How we express logic
  • ğŸ§  How we describe algorithms
  • ğŸ¤– How we talk to machines

Clean Python = Clear Thinking

item.title: Lecture 03 â€” Math Behind Intelligence
item.description:
~2â€“3 hours (core AI math intuition)

ğŸ“ Why Math Matters (Truth First)

Letâ€™s be honest.

Most people think:

â€œAI = magic + code + GPUâ€

Reality:

AI = math making good guesses under uncertainty

AI does NOT:

  • know the truth
  • understand like humans
  • think with meaning

AI estimates probabilities.

ğŸ§  One Sentence That Explains All AI

AI is a machine that guessesâ€¦ and learns how to guess better.

Math is how we:

  • define â€œbetterâ€
  • measure mistakes
  • improve guesses

ğŸ¯ Core Idea: Uncertainty Is Everywhere

Examples:

  • Is this email spam? â“
  • Is this image a cat or dog? â“
  • What word comes next? â“

AI never knows 100%.

So it asks:

â€œHow confident am I?â€

That confidence is probability.

ğŸ“Š Probability (Human Version)

Imagine this situation:

You hear meowing behind a door ğŸ±
Whatâ€™s behind the door?

  • Cat? ğŸ±
  • Dog? ğŸ¶
  • Robot cat? ğŸ¤–ğŸ±

You update your belief based on evidence.

That is probability.

ğŸ§® Bayesâ€™ Rule (The Brain of AI)

ğŸ§  Formula (donâ€™t panic)

$$ P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A)P(A)}{P(B)} $$

ğŸ§’ Human Translation

â€œHow likely A is, after seeing evidence B.â€

ğŸ˜„ Funny Example: Is Your Friend Late?

Let:

  • A = â€œFriend is lazyâ€
  • B = â€œFriend is lateâ€

We want:

Is your friend lazy given that they are late?

Step-by-step

Assume:

  • P(friend is lazy) = 0.3
  • P(friend is late | lazy) = 0.8
  • P(friend is late) = 0.5

Now calculate:

$$ P(lazy|late) = \frac{0.8 \times 0.3}{0.5} = 0.48 $$

ğŸ‘‰ You are now 48% suspicious ğŸ˜„

ğŸ¤– Why Bayes Matters in AI

Used in:

  • spam detection
  • medical diagnosis
  • robotics
  • decision-making

AI is constantly updating beliefs.

ğŸ“‰ Loss Function â€” How AI Feels Pain

AI learns by making mistakes.

Loss function answers:

â€œHow bad was this mistake?â€

ğŸ¯ Example: Guessing a Number

True value = 10
AI predicts = 7

Error = 3

But how painful is that?

ğŸ”¹ Mean Squared Error (MSE)

Formula: $$ MSE = \frac{1}{n} \sum (y - \hat{y})^2 $$

Example:


True = 10
Predicted = 7
Error = 3
Squared = 9

Why square?

  • no negative errors
  • punish big mistakes more

ğŸ¤¯ Cross-Entropy (VERY IMPORTANT)

Used in:

  • classification
  • language models
  • ChatGPT

Simple idea:

â€œHow surprised is the model?â€

ğŸ² Coin Example (Easy)

True answer:

  • Heads = 1
  • Tails = 0

Model predicts:

  • Heads = 0.9

Cross-entropy loss: $$ L = -\log(0.9) \approx 0.105 $$

Good prediction â†’ small loss ğŸ˜„
Bad prediction â†’ huge loss ğŸ˜±

ğŸ’¬ Why ChatGPT Uses Cross-Entropy

ChatGPT predicts:

â€œWhat is the next word?â€

If itâ€™s confident and correct â†’ low loss
Confident but wrong â†’ BIG loss

Thatâ€™s how it learns language.

ğŸ§  Neural Network = Function Machine

A neural network is:

A very flexible math function


Input â†’ Weighted sum â†’ Activation â†’ Output

ğŸ” Feedforward (Forward Pass)

This is thinking.

Steps:

  1. Input data
  2. Multiply by weights
  3. Apply activation
  4. Output prediction

No learning yet.

ğŸ˜– Backpropagation (Learning Moment)

Backpropagation answers:

â€œWhich weights caused the mistake?â€

Steps:

  1. Compute loss
  2. Send error backward
  3. Update weights slightly

Thatâ€™s learning.

ğŸ“‰ Gradient Descent (Walking Down a Hill)

Imagine youâ€™re blindfolded ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ¦¯ on a hill.

You:

  • feel the slope
  • step downhill
  • repeat

Eventually â†’ bottom.

Thatâ€™s gradient descent.

ğŸ§® Tiny Numeric Example

Loss = (w âˆ’ 5)Â²

Start:

  • w = 1

Gradient:

  • derivative = 2(w âˆ’ 5) = -8

Update:


w = w - learning_rate * gradient
w = 1 - 0.1 * (-8)
w = 1.8

Closer to 5 ğŸ‘

ğŸ§  Why Math Is Not Scary

Math in AI is:

  • measuring belief
  • measuring mistakes
  • adjusting guesses

Not magic. Not monsters. Just logic.

ğŸ¤– How All Math Connects

Concept Purpose
Probability Belief
Bayes Update belief
Loss Measure mistake
Cross-entropy Surprise
Gradient Direction to improve
Backprop Credit assignment

ğŸŒ Final Big Insight

AI does not understand truth.
It minimizes loss.

Understanding this makes you:

  • a better engineer
  • a better researcher
  • a wiser human

ğŸŒ± Final Reflection

Why do humans reason probabilistically instead of perfectly?

Because the world is uncertain â€” and intelligence means adapting.

item.title: Lecture 04 â€” Data: The Fuel of AI
item.description:
~1.5â€“2 hours (core understanding lecture)

ğŸ“¦ What Is Data? (Simple but Deep)

Data is recorded experience.

Everything AI knows comes from data.

Examples:

  • Images ğŸ–¼ï¸ â†’ what the world looks like
  • Text ğŸ“š â†’ how humans think & speak
  • Audio ğŸ§ â†’ how humans sound
  • Numbers ğŸ”¢ â†’ measurements, behavior, signals

No data = no learning
Better data = better intelligence

ğŸ§  A Powerful Truth

AI does not see reality.
AI sees data.

This difference explains almost every AI failure.

ğŸ§© Types of Data (With Intuition)

ğŸ–¼ï¸ Image Data

  • Photos
  • Medical scans
  • Satellite images

AI learns:

  • shapes
  • textures
  • patterns

But not meaning.

ğŸ“š Text Data

  • Books
  • Articles
  • Code
  • Conversations

AI learns:

  • grammar
  • logic patterns
  • style

Not truth. Not intention.

ğŸ§ Audio Data

  • Speech
  • Music
  • Noise

AI learns:

  • frequency patterns
  • pronunciation
  • rhythm

ğŸ”¢ Tabular / Numeric Data

  • Excel sheets
  • Databases
  • Logs

Used in:

  • finance
  • healthcare
  • business

ğŸ¥ Video Data

  • Images over time
  • Motion + sound

Hardest data type.

ğŸ”€ Multimodal Data (Modern AI)

Text + Image + Audio together.

Examples:

  • GPT-4V
  • Gemini
  • CLIP

Multimodal AI sees the world more like humans â€” but still imperfectly.

ğŸ§  Data vs Information vs Knowledge

Concept Meaning
Data Raw facts
Information Structured data
Knowledge Patterns learned
Wisdom Human judgment

AI stops at patterns.

Humans add meaning.

ğŸ˜„ Funny Example: Teaching a Kid vs AI

You show a kid:

  • 1 picture of a dog ğŸ¶

The kid understands.

You show an AI:

  • 1 picture of a dog

The AI learns nothing.

AI needs:

  • thousands
  • millions
  • billions of examples

Why? Because AI does not understand context.

âš ï¸ Garbage In = Garbage Out (GIGO)

Classic rule:

Bad data â†’ bad AI

Examples:

  • Biased hiring data â†’ biased hiring AI
  • Incomplete medical data â†’ dangerous predictions
  • Noisy labels â†’ confused models

Models donâ€™t fix data problems. They amplify them.

ğŸ§  What Is Bias? (Clear Definition)

Bias means:

Data does not represent reality fairly.

Sources:

  • Historical inequality
  • Sampling errors
  • Human prejudice
  • Missing groups

AI learns our past, not our ideals.

ğŸ˜¬ Real-World Example (Easy to Feel)

If all training images of â€œCEOâ€ are:

  • mostly men

AI learns:

CEO = man

Not because AI is evil â€”
but because data told it so.

ğŸ§’ Ethics for Kids (Simple Question)

Would you trust a robot that learned everything from one person?

Of course not.

Diversity of data = fairness.

âš–ï¸ Ethics for Adults (Serious Truth)

Data decisions are power decisions:

  • Who is included?
  • Who is missing?
  • Who defines labels?

These choices shape society.

ğŸ§  Data Is Not Neutral

Important myth:

â€œData is objective.â€

Reality:

  • Data is collected by humans
  • Labeled by humans
  • Filtered by humans

Therefore:

Data contains values.

ğŸ§ª Data Lifecycle (How AI Is Really Built)

  1. Collect data
  2. Clean data
  3. Label data
  4. Split data (train / val / test)
  5. Train model
  6. Evaluate
  7. Deploy
  8. Monitor drift

Most failures happen at steps 1â€“4.

ğŸ¤– Why Big Models Need Big Data

ChatGPT was trained on:

  • massive text corpora
  • diverse sources

Not because itâ€™s smart â€”
but because scale matters.

More data â†’ better generalization (to a point).

ğŸ§  Small Data Still Matters

In:

  • medicine
  • law
  • robotics

We must:

  • be careful
  • use domain knowledge
  • avoid blind automation

ğŸ” Data Leakage (Silent Killer)

Data leakage = test data sneaks into training.

Result:

  • fake high accuracy
  • real-world failure

Always separate data properly.

ğŸŒ Data Drift (Why Models Fail Over Time)

World changes. Data changes. Models decay.

Examples:

  • language evolves
  • behavior changes
  • environments shift

AI must be maintained, not worshiped.

ğŸ¤– Data Is the Memory of AI

AI has no childhood. No intuition. No experience.

Data is its memory of the world.

Choose memory wisely.

ğŸ§  Big Takeaways

  • Data shapes intelligence
  • Bias is unavoidable, but manageable
  • Ethics starts at data collection
  • Models reflect us

ğŸŒ± Final Reflection

If AI reflects society, what responsibility do we have as data creators?

To be careful, inclusive, and wise.

item.title: Lecture 05 â€” Types of Machine Learning
item.description:
~3 hours (core AI taxonomy lecture)

ğŸ§  Big Picture (Read This First)

Machine Learning = systems that improve performance by learning from experience.

But here is the secret:

Not all experience teaches the same way.

Different problems â†’ different learning paradigms.

If you choose the wrong type, even the best model will fail.

ğŸ§­ A Simple Mental Map

Think of learning like school:

Learning Type Analogy
Supervised Teacher gives answers
Unsupervised Student explores alone
Semi-supervised Few answers, many questions
Self-supervised Student creates own homework
Reinforcement Learning by reward & punishment

1ï¸âƒ£ Supervised Learning

â€œLearning with a teacherâ€

ğŸ“˜ Definition

Learning from labeled data:


(input â†’ correct output)

Examples:

  • image â†’ label (cat / dog)
  • email â†’ spam / not spam
  • house features â†’ price

ğŸ§  Intuition (Human Version)

A teacher says:

â€œThis is a cat.â€
â€œThis is NOT a cat.â€

The student adjusts until mistakes are small.

ğŸ§ª Classic Problems

ğŸ”¹ Classification

  • spam detection
  • medical diagnosis
  • fraud detection

ğŸ”¹ Regression

  • house price prediction
  • temperature forecasting

ğŸ’» Mini Project (Beginner-Friendly)

ğŸ¯ Project: Email Spam Classifier

Steps:

  1. Collect labeled emails
  2. Convert text â†’ numbers
  3. Train a classifier
  4. Evaluate accuracy
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer

texts = ["free money", "meeting tomorrow"]
labels = [1, 0]  # 1=spam, 0=not spam

vec = CountVectorizer()
X = vec.fit_transform(texts)

model = LogisticRegression()
model.fit(X, labels)

ğŸ‘‰ This is real AI, not magic.

â“ Quiz

Why does supervised learning need labels?

Because the loss function compares predictions with ground truth.

2ï¸âƒ£ Unsupervised Learning

â€œLearning without answersâ€

ğŸ“˜ Definition

Learning patterns without labels.

The system asks:

â€œWhat structure exists here?â€

ğŸ˜„ Funny Example

You walk into a party with strangers.

No name tags.

Your brain automatically groups people:

  • similar clothes
  • similar behavior
  • similar interests

Thatâ€™s clustering.

ğŸ§ª Common Techniques

  • K-means clustering
  • PCA (dimensionality reduction)
  • Topic modeling

ğŸ’» Mini Project

ğŸ¯ Project: Customer Segmentation

from sklearn.cluster import KMeans

X = [[20, 500], [25, 700], [45, 2000]]  # age, spending
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=2)
kmeans.fit(X)

print(kmeans.labels_)

Used in:

  • marketing
  • recommendation systems
  • anomaly detection

â“ Quiz

Is unsupervised learning useful without labels?

Yes â€” it discovers structure and representations.

3ï¸âƒ£ Semi-Supervised Learning

â€œA few answers, many questionsâ€

ğŸ“˜ Definition

Small labeled dataset + Large unlabeled dataset

ğŸ§  Why This Exists

Labeling costs:

  • money ğŸ’°
  • time â³
  • experts ğŸ§ 

But raw data is everywhere.

ğŸ§ª Real-World Uses

  • medical images
  • legal documents
  • speech recognition

ğŸ’» Mini Project Idea

Label:

  • 100 images by hand

Let the model:

  • infer the rest

This is how real-world AI systems survive.

â“ Quiz

Why is semi-supervised learning practical?

Labels are expensive; data is cheap.

4ï¸âƒ£ Self-Supervised Learning

â€œThe AI creates its own teacherâ€

ğŸ“˜ Definition

Labels are automatically generated from data itself.

ğŸ¤¯ Why This Changed AI Forever

Instead of humans saying:

â€œThis is the answerâ€

The system asks:

â€œWhat part of the data is missing?â€

ğŸ§ª Famous Examples

ğŸ”¹ NLP

  • Masked word prediction (BERT)

ğŸ”¹ Vision

  • Predict image rotation
  • Contrastive learning (CLIP)

ğŸ’» Mini Project (Conceptual)

Input: "AI is ____"
Target: "powerful"

This simple idea trained LLMs.

â“ Quiz

Why is self-supervised learning powerful?

It scales with data, not human labeling.

5ï¸âƒ£ Reinforcement Learning (RL)

â€œLearning by doingâ€

ğŸ“˜ Definition

Learning from reward signals, not correct answers.

ğŸ•¹ï¸ Intuition

You train a dog ğŸ•:

  • Good behavior â†’ treat
  • Bad behavior â†’ no treat

No explicit instructions.

ğŸ§ª Key Components

Term Meaning
Agent Learner
Environment World
Action Choice
Reward Feedback

ğŸ’» Tiny RL Example (Concept)

if reward > 0:
    increase_probability(action)
else:
    decrease_probability(action)

Used in:

  • AlphaGo
  • robotics
  • recommendation systems
  • game AI

â“ Quiz

What is the explorationâ€“exploitation tradeoff?

Balancing trying new actions vs using known good ones.

ğŸ§  How These Power Modern AI

System Learning Type
ChatGPT Self-supervised + RLHF
Image AI Self-supervised + supervised
Robots Reinforcement learning
Recommenders Supervised + RL

ğŸ“ Final Big Insight

There is no â€œbestâ€ learning type. There is only the right tool for the problem.

Great AI engineers choose wisely.

ğŸŒ± Final Reflection

If you had unlimited data but no labels, which learning paradigm would you choose?

Self-supervised learning.

item.title: Lecture 06 â€” Data Types & Modalities
item.description:
~2â€“2.5 hours (core data understanding lecture)

ğŸŒ Big Idea (Read This First)

AI does not see the world like humans.
It sees data representations.

Understanding data modalities is understanding:

  • what AI can learn
  • what AI cannot learn
  • why some problems are harder than others

ğŸ“¦ Data Is Everything (But Not Equal)

AI performance is often limited by:

  • data quality
  • data quantity
  • data structure

Better model + bad data = bad AI
Simple model + good data = strong AI

ğŸ§  What Is a Modality?

A modality is:

A way information is represented.

Humans:

  • see ğŸ‘€
  • hear ğŸ‘‚
  • read ğŸ“–

AI:

item.title: Lecture 08 â€” Evaluation Metrics
item.description:

ğŸ“ Why Evaluation Metrics Matter (Truth First)

ğŸ§  One Sentence That Explains Metrics

ğŸ§ª A Running Example (Very Important)

ğŸ”¹ PART I â€” Classification Metrics

ğŸ§© Confusion Matrix (The Foundation)

ğŸ¯ Accuracy (The Most Misused Metric)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ Accuracy = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} $$

  • 990 healthy

ğŸ¯ Precision (How Careful Are You?)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ Precision = \frac{TP}{TP + FP} $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

When the model says â€œpositiveâ€, how often is it correct?

ğŸ˜„ Example (Spam Filter)

ğŸ¯ Recall (How Much Did You Catch?)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ Recall = \frac{TP}{TP + FN} $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

ğŸ˜„ Example (Medical Test)

  • 10 sick patients

$$ Recall = \frac{7}{10} = 0.7 $$

âš–ï¸ Precision vs Recall (Classic Tradeoff)

Metric Focus

ğŸ¯ F1 Score (The Balance)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ F1 = 2 \cdot \frac{Precision \cdot Recall}{Precision + Recall} $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

One number that balances both.

ğŸ˜„ Example

Precision = 0.8
Recall = 0.6

$$ F1 = 2 \cdot \frac{0.8 \cdot 0.6}{1.4} \approx 0.69 $$

Used when:

  • classes are imbalanced
  • both errors matter

ğŸ”¹ PART II â€” Regression Metrics

ğŸ¯ Mean Absolute Error (MAE)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ MAE = \frac{1}{n} \sum |y - \hat{y}| $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

ğŸ˜„ Example

  • |100âˆ’90| = 10
  • |200âˆ’210| = 10

$$ MAE = \frac{20}{2} = 10 $$

ğŸ¯ Mean Squared Error (MSE)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ MSE = \frac{1}{n} \sum (y - \hat{y})^2 $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

Punishes large mistakes more.

ğŸ˜„ Example

Errors: [10, 10]
Squares: [100, 100]

$$ MSE = 100 $$

Used when big errors are very bad.

ğŸ¯ Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)

ğŸ“ Formula

$$ RMSE = \sqrt{MSE} $$

ğŸ§  Meaning

Same unit as target variable.

If RMSE = 10 â†’ â€œaverage error â‰ˆ 10 unitsâ€

ğŸ”¹ PART III â€” NLP Metrics (Language Is Hard)

ğŸ§  Why NLP Metrics Are Tricky

Language has:

  • multiple correct answers

  • synonyms

âœï¸ BLEU Score (Translation)

ğŸ”¹ PART IV â€” Metrics in the Real World
